content: The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen. The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen by amending the Internal Revenue Code to include fishing businesses in the definition of elected farm income. It also defines a fishing business as the conduct of commercial fishing. The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" includes fishing businesses in income averaging for fishermen by amending the Internal Revenue Code. It defines a fishing business as the conduct of commercial fishing as defined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR PURCHASE OF FISHING SAFETY EQUIPMENT. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section for a fishing safety equipment credit. The fishing safety equipment credit allows eligible taxpayers engaged in a fishing business to claim a credit of 75% of qualified fishing safety equipment expenses, up to a maximum of $1,500 per year. Qualified expenses include amounts paid for safety equipment used in connection with the fishing business. The fishing safety equipment credit allows eligible taxpayers in a fishing business to claim a credit for 75% of qualified expenses, up to $1,500 per year. Qualified expenses cover lifesaving equipment required on vessels. Special rules apply, including aggregation rules for certain employer groups. Special rules apply for the fishing safety equipment credit, including aggregation rules for certain employer groups. No double benefit deduction is allowed for the credit amount, and the basis of equipment is adjusted if a credit is claimed. The fishing safety equipment credit allows for a basis adjustment of equipment when the credit is claimed. There is a limitation on carrying back the credit before the effective date of the provision. The fishing safety equipment credit under section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a basis adjustment of equipment. The credit can be carried to a taxable year before the enactment of section 45D. Conforming amendments are made to sections 38(b) and 1016 of the Code to include the fishing safety equipment credit. The fishing safety equipment credit under section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a basis adjustment of equipment and can be carried to a taxable year before the enactment of section 45D. Amendments are made to sections 38(b) and 1016 of the Code to include the credit. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The fishing safety equipment credit under section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000.
